posts.name: Jp
posts.cooked:
We’ve implemented 6328’s 250Hz odometry implementation with a lot of success, however, we immediately started seeing the error:

Error 1003: CAN Frame not received / too stale. Please make sure device power, utilization…

We still can’t seem to find a way to remove this error, but we know that it is somewhere in our swerve code as when removing it and deploying, the error goes away. Not motors are giving any faults by themselves, nor the CANivore. Here is the code to our Kraken module code:

Has anyone experienced something similar? We weren’t able to find a solution, yet we did noticed the robot continued to operate normally even with the error. Regardless, we just want to remove it to be sure everything’s okay.

Thanks!
I’m not able to check the code right now but the first thing I’d look at is signal update frequency; you’ll probably need very high frequencies for all signals you use (>= 250Hz)

posts.name: Jp
posts.cooked: So like apply the 250hz frequency for all devices?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: Something I noticed is that you’re refreshing driveAcceleration and driveCurrent here , but you never seem to give them an update frequency in the constructor . Since you call optimizeBusUtilization() , it’s possible that one or both of these signals are being disabled.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.cooked: So, @AndromedaHelix ensure you set these and existing signals to 250Hz on all motors.

posts.name: Jp
posts.cooked: If I’ve set all my signals to either 250 or 50Hz, is there a problem if they have different frequencies? 6238’s base code has different frequencies for different signals, though I’ve noticed that in their robot code they have all motors on 100Hz. Maybe that could be more optimal?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked: As long as you’re not doing a waitForAll() with a non-zero timeout, the signals do not all need to be 250 Hz. All that matters is that all signals you use are given a non-zero update frequency. Since you’re using refreshAll() , setting driveAcceleration and driveCurrent to 50 Hz would be sufficient if you don’t need them any faster than that.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
bhall-ctre:

As long as you’re not doing a waitForAll() with a non-zero timeout

IIRC 6328 call waitForAll with a non zero timeout. But it’s also important to set update frequency with their code. I did set the update frequency correctly and have seen the exact same error as described in this post. Since it didn’t really affect anything I just ignored it, but if someone has any idea why this might happen I’d love to hear as well.

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
levyishai:

IIRC 6328 call waitForAll with a non zero timeout.

Correct, but only on signals passed into PhoenixOdometryThread.getInstance().registerSignal() . Since this only includes driveMotor.getPosition() and steeringMotor.getPosition() , you only need to make sure those two signals are running at 250 Hz.

levyishai:

I did set the update frequency correctly and have seen the exact same error as described in this post. Since it didn’t really affect anything I just ignored it, but if someone has any idea why this might happen I’d love to hear as well.

How often does it happen? It’s not unusual to get a couple stale frame warnings at startup, but it shouldn’t happen periodically. Also, is the error from a waitForAll() call or from refresh()/refreshAll() ?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: The error is from waitForAll() It’s not a constant error, but it’s also not uncommon. Happens now and then, which is why it was kind of negligible for me. But still seems like something we should find to root cause to. This doesn’t happen only on startup. Maybe just sending very fast frames is hard even for CAN FD?

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
The AdvantageKit template uses a timeout of twice the expected period on waitForAll (so 8ms at 250Hz), which matches CTRE ’s swerve code. My understanding is that the error is printed when that call times out. We’ve observed this with 6328’s competition code too, where it seems to time out periodically despite (approximately) keeping up with the 250 Hz rate. We are also separately looking into issues with our CANivore, including timestamp synchronization warnings (unclear if this is related).

For now, we’ve switched the timeout in our competition code to 20ms since that still enforces a minimum rate of 50Hz if a device is truly disconnected. We haven’t made any changes to the AdvantageKit template since it matches CTRE ’s code and we don’t have a definitive explanation yet.

posts.name: Jp
posts.cooked: This is exactly what happens to us, though with a greater frequency ( might be due to not having a frequency for driveAcceleration and driveCurrent). As you, we noticed it didn’t affect anything, but we would be happy to remove the error.

posts.name: Jp
posts.cooked: So you keep all frequencies at 100hz then?

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: I think he said they update at 250hz, but let waitForAll wait up to 50hz The other fequencies shouldn’t be affected since the problem is from waitForAll (at least for me I’ve seen the error’s root cause is only waitForAll ) which only calls the 250hz signals.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: Actually, maybe unrelated and already fixed, but I did notice that sometimes when setting update frequency for one signals it changes another’s frequency due to how the signals are sent through the CAN . This happened to me with Pigeon2’s pitch and yaw signals IIRC. Maybe one of the signals goes back to 100hz when changing another signals frequency and this causes this weird error. Kind of a long shot, and probably already fixed, but maybe it’s something similar.
